title: GT MK8 Auto level for Prusa i3 Pro B and Pro C or Mk8 setup

description.text:
My First 3D Printer Practicle part that anyone can use if they have an MK8 extruder. I have designed it to fit on the fan for a MK8 extruder and the fan on a Pro C dual extruder bracket which i will show next after i add a second extruder to my Pro B. This part can be installed on a Geeetch single extruder Prusa i3 Pro, Pro B, and Pro C Dual extruder with minor adjustments, some minor changes to certain firmware setups. check out my YouTube channel for the videos i did on this. My user name is: georgeroblesjr i will post my firmware on my wordpress page at georgeroblesjr.wordpress.com I will sell these or the parts you need on my online store if people ask for it. If you want to buy a printer from me and want great tech support, check out my online store: georges3dprinters.com
https://youtu.be/IcuFkOzr-5k
https://youtu.be/WtjIAIQPWlc

You will need 3-10mm x 6mm cylinder N52 magnets that you can order online, 2-M3 x 16mm screws, 1-M3 x 12mm screw, 1-M3 flat washer, and a push button switch of some sort like off an old TV remote or can buy one new for less then a $1.00. First push in magnets in the two spots they fit in. Remove the screws that hold on the cooling fan to the MK8 extruder (I did this one scew at a time so it would not come apart) and feed the scerws through the MK8 mounting bracket and replace the scews and parts as before. Next take the push button switch and solder on two wires to the two leads of the switch. These wires will be attached to the z min stop replacing the z axis min switch. make sure to remove any obstrutions from the orignal z end stop, like removing the screw which actuates it. In my case, it's on the x axis motor bracket and I had to just get it high enough that it was out the way. Take Z probe arm with the slot closest to you, with the holes on the side closest to the edge on the bottom,
take 1-M3 x 16mm screw and thread it through the furthest hole from the right going through the arm to the other side till when you see the threads come out. Then take the second M3 x 16mm screw and thread it in the hole closest to you from the left going through the arm to the other side till about 2mm of thread are showing. Next with the M3 flat washer on the M3 x 12mm screw, feed it through the the arm pivot point (piece with the slot for switch), mount with the holes on the side closest to the edge towards the MK8 mounting bracket and thread it in at the upper center raised screw mount. Lastly, take the third magnet and place on the head of the screw closest to the switch. At this point assembly is done and now you just have to adjust the screws, firmware, and type up some g-code to make it work. see what i did on my youtube channel, my user name is georgeroblesjr, and check out what i did to make mine work.

author: speed13764

description.text:
Another zinc casting in an ABS mold.  
See my other metal casting projects for more info.

[Update 5-31-16
Dang... The casting broke at the top of the stem, where a hole has been drilled (See photo). I pushed maybe 500 pellets through, and it eventually let go. Too much stress. Metal solidifies in crystals. Zinc has large crystals. Crystal boundaries are weak points. Large crystals boundaries in small sections like this stem-hole are a definite weakness. I think a casting like this might be heat treated after casting, to re-crystallize things, and to make it stronger. But anyway, too bad it broke. This piston was far superior to the OEM part. I may cast another one, or cut one from steel or aluminum... this was disappointing...
End.]
.....................
This is a zinc casting in an ABS mold. It may be the first really practical application I've found for 3D printed molds. I have a pellet rifle (Daisy 880) and am attempting some modifications. It has an integrated air pump. The piston on the end of the pump has an inefficient design, and might be improved. (Update: Photo of a typical, melted mold added for illustration. Also, my chronometer says there was a nice improvement of at least 70 FPS with 10 pumps and a 7g pellet. A properly fitted piston reduces air space at the end of the stroke, and forces more of the highest pressure air into the compression chamber.) I intended to cut a new piston from stock aluminum or steel rod, but had no raw material close to the required size. So I got to thinking about the possibility of casting an oversized blank, and machining that blank. The rifle's original piston is zinc. The pump tube is aluminum. A steel or aluminum piston might damage the tube. So I decided to follow the manufacturer's lead, make it from zinc, and minimizing unforeseen complications. The Featured photo shows the original piston on the left, and the cast replacement on the right. They are approximately 1.3" tall (33mm) and 0.75 diameter (19mm).
The mold design is a simple two sided box. Printing a set took 90 minutes with Afinia defaults, except for 0.35mm layers to save some time. 72 grams ABS. The cast part is somewhat larger than the original piston, and was lathe turned down to the proper dimensions. I had never turned zinc and didn't know what to expect. It turns quite well. Zinc was melted in a 400W Palmer Hot Pot electric ladle, capable of about 950 F, commonly used for casting lead fishing weights, bullets, and the like. This zinc solidified (seriously lost fluidity) at about 710 F, and was gravity poured slightly above that, near 725 F to 730 F. I use a multimeter with a temperature function and its submersible wire thermocouple to accurately measure the melt temperature. There was only a wisp of smoke before removing the cast part from the softened mold.

Casting metal has many dangers. Do not cast metal unless you have the knowledge and proper equipment, and know and follow all the safety precautions. It's a fun and useful hobby but it's not one to be taken lightly.   
See my other metal casting projects for various information. To resize these SAE files to Metric, scale up by a factor of 25.4.

comments.text: Hi,
comments.author: stormychel

comments.text:
Evidently a comment must be a single paragraph to be viewed so I'm scrunching this one up into one paragraph. Hi, Sorry for the delayed reply. Notification of your comment was not emailed to me for some reason.
Casting has been a lifetime hobby... tried just about everything, by just about every method I could think of. I eventually found employment in an art foundry, and all we did was lost wax casting, mostly bronze. So I know what you mean.
Haven't tried burning out PLA. If it flows like wax then that should work ok. How can you know when it has drained from the nooks and crannys inside the mold? Suppose there's a pocket where it just sits there.
Wax does not just melt and drain away. Some melts into the surface of the plaster. If hot metal hits that surface, it vaporizes the wax, and gas bubbles and other surface defects can be expected.
So, after draining a majority of wax (or using an autoclave) the molds are burned out to a red heat, which is scheduled and takes a long time... Some of our molds required days in a burnout oven.
Additionally, plaster takes hours to set. A printed mold might require a couple hours to print, and you're ready to pour.
Lost-wax is worth the effort when a fine surface is desired. Whether a print is the model or it is the mold, it doesn't have a smooth surface, so the primary benefit of lost-wax is lost. Wax is easy to tool, where PLA and ABS and everything else can't be modeled and smoothed out. (There is one filament blend which claims to have good modeling qualities but I haven't tried it.)
I actually have a list of reasons I wouldn't combine printing with the lost-wax technique. (I also spent a lot of effort trying to remove printed patterns from plaster molds without using heat... instead doing it chemically.. among other things.)
But everything has its place, and I wouldn't discourage anyone from doing whatever is best for their unique project.
Hi, this is where I got the idea from : http://www.bing.com/videos/search?q=lost+pla+casting&form=HDRSC3&first=1#view=detail&mid=4A0A38290C162420D08E4A0A38290C162420D08E
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text: hmmm... Something's funky about these Thingiverse comments today. I only see the first paragraph of a comment, including mine, unless I select "Edit" and then my whole comment appears. Can't "edit" anyone else's so I can't even read them. So I'm scrunching this one into one paragraph. I would notify Support, but their Captcha is also on the blink, and won't accept messages.You probably got the whole thing in an email so I'll assume you read the long reply I left you last night. If not, say so. I saw that video before, and watched it again today. My feeling is he's experienced and competent. Just don't expect the video to provide all the information a beginner needs to know to cast a part with that method, because of course it can't. A lot is taken for granted, or left out. Lost-wax (lost PLA, lost-foam, lost cow dung?, lost-anything) is an ancient technique and well proven. A 3D printer is a great tool for making accurate, sacrificial patterns. Plaster (or more properly "casting investment" which includes vital components beyond plaster of paris) is widely available. Ovens and furnaces can be built... done that.. I've made graphite / clay crucibles and fired them in a home-built kiln. My point is there's nothing to stop someone from doing it if they want to. I say go for it.
I tried ABS cast with low temp. Bismuth-Cad alloy, and never think ABS works with high temp Zn of over 370 deg Cel ! Are you using Zn alloy as I think Zn melting point is over 400 deg C
comments.author: airforce

comments.text: One more thing.. I've used only ABS. I do not know if PLA will work. I've never tried it.
comments.author: airforce

comments.text: I've done lots of metal casting... bronze, silver... Even earned money doing it... and I never thought it would work. It's a very strange situation. One day I tried aluminum (at near 650C) and was amazed..

title: LED Keychain Light

description.text:
Approximate project cost: <$1
Max print dimensions 56 x 30 x 8mm Want a super easy and quick project to print and build? Well, this project ticks the boxes and it’s useful for anyone, making it a great gift idea! Everyone needs a keychain light for those dark nights when you can’t find the keyhole to your front door or for when the lights go out! Made up of only 2 small printed components and only 2 electronic components, this little guy only takes about 30 minutes to print and a few minutes to put together! The electronics kit contains components to make 10x LED keychain lights! So not only can you make one for your own set of keys but you can print them for your family and friends too! Once you've downloaded the complete STL files visit http://www.project3dprint.com for direct links to purchase the electronics yourself for this project. In the mean time you can get printing!

Ladies and Gents! Meet the bull! For the Air Softer. This is designed to snugly fit onto a HFC \"M190 Special Force\" airsoft pistol.
The M190 has a simple rail below the barrel. This component will slide on, and lock in place. This is designed to hold 'laser pointers' with an average width 17mm or flash light with similar dimensions.

Parts Required:
2x M3x18 Bolts
2x M3 Washers
2x M3 Nuts
Laser Rail Mount (Printed)
(Laser pointer or flash light) Assemble as shown in the images. Depending on your laser or lights button configuration, the mount will make the device turn on while bolts are tightened. It is preferred that the device chosen has a toggle switch on the butt end. This will allow the user to switch the device on or off at will, rather then having to use an hex wrench to turn off.

comments.text:
You don't have to restrict yourself to a single type of clutch:
In a conventional modern automotive transmission, there are basically two clutches per gear, a friction clutch (the synchro mesh) which is used just to get the pieces in synch, and a dog clutch that is used to do the actual power transmission.

title: Fonctional eolienne with Darrieus propeller and axial flux generator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello, Here is my wind turbine that is fully printed PLA. All other parts for assembly are easily found online or in stores. It is fully functional (it is still in process but I will put my page updated with new photos and comments) She is "vertical axis" to facilitate the passage of electrical son but can be installed horizontally (eg a roof) It consists of a Darrieus type of propeller that is light and easy to build with a 3D printer (multipart). It has an average return but works regardless of the wind direction and even with very strong winds. To produce electricity, I printed a generator "axial flux" PLA. It works perfectly, it mainly consists of a brass plate coils (electrical power depends on the diameter of the wire used) and two plates of neodymium magnets. I have a small printer (micro delta) that I use to its limits so usually everyone can print all the files on all other printers. (In case of problems, do not hesitate to contact me to find a solution together) Propeller Darrieus: It consists of three vertical blades which are offset by 120 degrees. Each blade measures 60 cm high and 11 cm wide. To print, I have modeled several parts that are assembled with two threaded rods M5 brass. All the blades are secured with stainless steel tubes of 10 mm in diameter. Axial flux generator: The central plateau is made up of 9 coils connected in series star and PLA bonded between two pieces (with an epoxy adhesive). I used 0.5mm diameter copper 9x 15 meters. The magnet plates are made of neodymium magnets 20mmx10mmx10mm 12 each. They are also attached with an epoxy adhesive. All metal used is stainless steel except the threaded rods which are made of brass (to be cheaper). I "straightens" then the current with two diode bridges connected between the three phases. I hope I was clear in my explanations, but I can do the diagrams if necessary. Do not hesitate to contact me directly to my email address ([email protected]) if you need me to help you build or I send you some items. Goog print. I have posted online a support for fixing the wind turbine on a 40mm diameter tube but the part of the generator is modeled with several mounting holes so you can easily model a support adapted to your needs.
If you have problems to model, do not hesitate to contact me. Hello everyone,
The contest is now over but I will continue to make changes to improve current production with the wind turbine whenever possible.
Particular, I would add a set of gears with gear 1: 5 or 1: 6 to use the maximum capacity of the generator.
I really hope to win first prize to push the limits of my little printer and make a new more powerful version of wind turbine.
Thank you all for your monitor and your feedbacks.
Good print. French : Bonjour, Voici mon eolienne qui est entièrement imprimée en PLA. Toutes les autres pièces pour l'assemblage se trouvent facilement sur internet ou en magasin. Elle est complètement fonctionnelle (elle est encore en cours de fabrication mais je mettrai ma page à jour avec des photos et des nouveaux commentaires) Elle est à "axe vertical" pour faciliter le passage des fils électriques mais elle peut être installée horizontalement (sur un toit par exemple) Elle est constituée d'une helice de type Darrieus qui est légère et facile à construire avec une imprimante 3d (en plusieurs parties). Elle a un rendement moyen mais fonctionne quelque soit la direction du vent et même avec des vents très importants. Pour produire l'électricité, j'ai imprimé un générateur "à flux axial" en PLA. Il fonctionne parfaitement, il est constitué principalement d'un plateau de bobines de cuivres (la puissance électrique dépend du diamètre du fil utilisé) et de deux plateaux d'aimants neodyme. J'ai une petite imprimante (micro delta) que j'utilise jusqu'à ses limites donc normalement tout le monde peut imprimer tous les fichiers sur toutes les autres imprimantes. (En cas de problèmes, n'hésitez pas à me contacter pour trouver une solution ensemble) Helice Darrieus : Elle est constituée de trois pales verticales qui sont décalées de 120 degrés. Chaque pale mesure 60 cm de hauteur et 11 cm de large. Pour pouvoir les imprimer, je les ai modélisées en plusieurs parties qui sont assemblées avec deux tiges filetées M5 en laiton. Toutes les pales sont fixées avec des tubes inox de 10 mm de diamètre. Générateur à flux axial : Le plateau central est constitué de 9 bobinages montés en série en étoile et collés entre deux pièces de PLA (avec une colle epoxy). J'ai utilisé du cuivre de 0.5mm de diamètre 9x 15 mètres. Les plateaux d'aimants sont constitués de 12 aimants néodyme 20mmx10mmx10mm chacun. Ils sont également fixés avec une colle epoxy. Tout le métal utilisé est en inox, sauf les tiges filetées qui sont en laiton (pour être moins chères). Je "redresse" ensuite le courant avec deux ponts de diodes montées entre les trois phases. J'espère avoir été clair dans mes explications, mais je peux vous faire des schémas si besoin. N'hésitez pas à me contacter directement sur mon adresse mail ([email protected]) si vous avez besoin que je vous aide à construire ou que je vous envoi certains éléments. Goog print. J'ai posté en ligne un support pour fixer l'eolienne sur un tube de 40mm de diamètre mais la partie du générateur est modélisée avec plusieurs trous de fixation donc vous pouvez modéliser facilement un support adapté à vos besoins.
Si vous avez des problèmes pour modéliser, n'hésitez pas à me contacter. Bonjour à tous,
Le concours est maintenant terminé mais je continuerais à apporter des modifications pour améliorer la production de courant avec cette éolienne autant que possible.
Je voudrais notamment ajouter un jeu d'engrenages avec une démultiplication de 1 pour 5 ou 1 pour 6 pour utiliser le maximum des capacités du générateur.
J'espère vraiment gagner le premier prix pour repousser les limites de ma petite imprimante et fabriquer une nouvelle version plus puissante d'éolienne.
Merci à tous pour votre suivi et vos feedbacks.
Good print.

Propeller: For the propeller, all parts are printed. For the blades, I use a PLA with 15% filling (They are lightweight but very resistant because they are assembled with the threaded rods M5).
You need 6 M5 threaded studs length 620mm.
The two plates that hold the blades together are fastened together with 3 tubes 10mm length 320mm diameter.
(I use stainless steel tubes but can be replaced by aluminum tubes, lighter and cheaper)
You need 6 more 10mm diameter tubes for assemble blades, the length depends on the diameter of the propeller that you want. Generator: All structural components are also printed. I also use PLA with 50% fill to withstand very large stresses. You need two ball bearings (10x26x8), a stainless steel tube of 10mm in diameter 100mm in length, four threaded rods M5 100mm length and a length of 120mm.
You also need two rings to keep the bearings in the right place. using two aluminum tubes 12mm in diameter, a length of 11.5mm and a length of 5mm. I use the enameled copper wire diameter 0.3mm to 9 coils (the larger the diameter, the smaller the voltage, the greater the power is low) I posted STL files to assist in the production of coils with a drill or screwdriver, but you can do them by hand ... There are comments on the reels but please contact me for further information. You also need 24 neodymium magnets 20x10x10. All other screws and bolts are very classic and are easily found in any DIY store (or on the internet ...) All pieces are modeled for my small printer so they should take all other printers. If you have any problems do not hesitate to contact me. Good print French : Hélice : Pour l'hélice, toutes les pièces sont imprimées. Pour les pales, j'utilise du PLA avec un remplissage de 15% (Elles sont légères mais très résistantes car elles sont assemblées avec des tiges filetées M5.)
Vous avez besoin de 6 tiges filetées M5 de 620mm de longueur.
Les deux plateaux qui tiennent les pales ensembles sont fixés ensemble avec 3 tubes de 10mm de diamètre de 320mm de longueur.
(J'utilise des tubes d'inox mais on peut les remplacer par des tubes d'aluminium, plus légers et moins chers
Vous avez besoin de 6 autres tubes de 10mm de diamètre pour assembler les pales, la longueur dépend du diamètre de l'hélice que vous souhaitez. Générateur : Toutes les pièces de structure sont aussi imprimées. J'utilise aussi du PLA avec 50% de remplissage pour résister aux très grandes contraintes. Vous avez besoin de deux roulements à bille (10x26x8), d'un tube d'inox de 10mm de diamètre de 100 mm de longueur, de quatre tiges filetées M5 de 100mm de longueur et une de 120mm de longueur.
Vous avez aussi besoin de deux bagues pour maintenir les roulements à la bonne place. j'utilise deux petits tubes d'aluminium de 12mm de diamètre, un de 11,5mm de longueur et un de 5mm de longueur. J'utilise du fil de cuivre enameled de 0.3mm de diamètre pour faire les 9 bobines (plus le diamètre est petit, plus le voltage est grand et plus la puissance est faible) J'ai posté des fichiers STL pour aider à la fabrication des bobines avec une perceuse ou une visseuse, mais on peut les faire à la main... Il y a des commentaires sur les bobines mais contactez moi pour d'autres informations. Vous avez aussi besoin de 24 aimants neodyme 20x10x10. Toutes les autres vis et boulons sont très classiques et se trouvent facilement dans tous les magasins de bricolage (ou sur internet...) Toutes les pièces sont modélisées pour ma petite imprimante donc elles devraient tenir dans toutes les autres imprimantes. Si vous rencontrez des problèmes n'hésitez pas à me contacter. Good print

L'éolienne ne produit que quelques volts avec une faible intensité.
Séparément, l'hélice et le générateur fonctionnent très bien. L'hélice est très stable mais est conçue pour tourner lentement (même par forts vents) par contre, pour être efficace, le générateur doit tourner très vite et est donc plus adapté à un montage sur une éolienne à axe horizontal traditionnelle.
Je suis en train de retravailler sur mon projet.

Adapter un générateur de type moyeu de roue de vélo sur l'hélice (on en trouve en 12v, sont conçus pour tourner lentement et sont étanches)
Adapter sur l'hélice un générateur 12v avec démultiplication intégrée. Type générateur "à main" avec engrenage planétaire.
À bientôt
Xavier

This is a simply supported beam with a fixed and roller support on each end printed as one piece. The supports rotate freely on a pin-like system. This is great for visualizing concepts in engineering mechanics (statics, strength of materials, etc.) such as: deflection, yield strength, etc. Great teaching tool or if you just want a cool novelty item to keep on your desk. If you are an engineering student or professor/teacher, THIS IS FOR YOU! Seriously though, take advantage of it you will learn more than one would expect. Let me know if there are any requests for different types of beams and maybe I will whip something up for ya and upload it. Enjoy:)

Upload and make sure it is built with the supports facing up. Print with as much or as little infill as you desire. Best results if you have good bridging for the supports. Obviously more infill = stronger beam and vis-versa. So, one thing I did is experiment with the different infills to see how it effects the deflection and yield strength of the beam.

description.text: Video in action https://youtu.be/Yj91v6HAUrc This is my first simple robot built from leftovers. Left here for inspiration mostly. The board mount is for those radio-shack boards. (I'll add the openscad files when I get around to adding the licensing stuff at the top.) The whiskers can be printed then cut to fit. All this can be built on the printrbot simple metal. The motors I used were the gear motors from solarbotics. https://solarbotics.com/product/gm2/ The brain is a Arduino pro mini https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11113 If I had to do it again I would make a printed circuit board to make the connections - as there were a lot of wires. I used an h-bridge part to drive the motors from the Arduino https://www.sparkfun.com/products/315 While I did add solar sensors to detect light - it made the robot be have poorly (having it bump into things made it behave better - no more going in circles and more exploring)

Note - let the robot base cool down on a heated bed before you attempt to pull it off or you'll bend the base.  
All the hardware is M3 screws of various needed lengths I got at home depot.  I used hot glue for mounting the other things.
Lets you keep your scissors on your fridge. The one that came with the scissors broke, so I did what most people on this site would do... created my own.

description.text: like my wire clip but this one is to run wires along a wall

Pulled from: https://grabcad.com/library/bb-rt-01-100-es-slewing-ring-bearing The original design was scaled to fit two sizes of balls and mounting holes:
All 5x scaled parts - balls and holes 3 mm;
All 10x scaled parts - balls and holes 6 mm. It has 60 balls that can be printed or bought separately. This is intended for use in a robot arm, and a driving gear is available:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:885159

4 turn helical for 5.8GHz FPV for goggle mounting. A 4 turn helical has a wide(ish) beam of around 50 degrees and will increase range of your FPV setup over the usual skew planar/cloverleaf to skew planar. The wide beam of a 4 turn should allow you to 'track' your plane/quad using your own head movements(perhaps not 360 degrees but I'm sure you get the idea).
This will work for right and left polarisation, just download the former in the files that suits.
See instructions for other stuff needed ;) For an even wider beam but slightly less gain my 3 turn version can be found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:883293

Other than the printed parts you will need, some 1-1.2mm diameter single core copper wire(lighting twin and earth is good), a piece of double sided copper clad PCB board cut into a 52mm(maybe 51.5mm) diameter circle, semi rigid RG402 coax with whatever connector your goggles take( very cheap on ebay with connectors already fitted from china, just cut in half to make 2!), a small piece of wire,a small piece of copper 6.4mmx3.2mm(I cut mine from a piece of copper pipe), solder, and glue. Drill a 4mm hole 8.75mm from the centre of the pcb disc, drill a second hole that lines up with the recess in the inside of the reflector holder. Solder a wire through this second hole to join the front and back of the copper on the pcb. Place lead support on coax and slide down out of the way, then strip back about 5mm of metal shielding of the coax and open up into a cross shape, solder this on the back of the PCB with the internal wire going through the hole. Form your coil with the former, make 4 1/3 turns and thread through the main support. Glue everything together and then wind the coil back slightly to align with the tip of the coax signal wire and solder into place. Cut any excess coil away level with the edge of the top hole in the main support to make 4 turns exactly. Solder the small piece of copper(wave trap) along the coil in the centre of the first 1/4 turn.
Finally attach to goggles and fly ;) The printing is all straight forward, no supports are needed anywhere.

Here's a cube with three things held captive in it. I used ZBrush to carve curved passages inside the cube and then snaked the things through them. Smaller cubes and spheres hold the things captive. author: DeltaLambda

title: Mendel X Y axis accuracy doubling mod.

description.text: Ok I'm writing this all for a second time as I accidentally deleted evrything. Noooooooooooo. This mod doubles the X Y axisâ€™s accuracy on Reprap Mendel. It does this by creating a double pulley system. I have noticed that there is significantly less lash on my x axis now and everything seems to move more sharply. Another benefit is this mod allows your machine to run at exactly the same speed as before. http://youtu.be/vVHvbCfxZdU You can see the first test here and get a good idea of how it goes together. The only difference now is the Y belts brackets have all captured knuts and countersunk bolts.

Instructions.
Hardware. 12 M4 by 20mm countersunk bolts. M4 studding. 4 624ZZ bearings. (The same ones used on all the bets.) Some longer M4 bolts. M4 standard and lock knuts. M4 washers. T5 belting 5m long. M3 knuts.
Open T5 belting can be obtained here.
http://www.beltingonline.com/t5-standard-breco-open-length-timing-belt-1738
The bearings fit in to the bating brackets with an M4 washer wither side. An M4 bolt is then passed through with a washer either side and the whole lot is clamped. It is best to not tighten the Y axis baring clamp until it is bolted down or it can make it hard to get the base bolts in. You should be able to reuse the old X and Y clamp bolts. The Y axis baring bracket has 4 M3 knuts captured in it.
The X axis belt clamps need 4 M4 studs made about 85mm long. They screw in to the captured knuts that are next to the z screw knuts. Donâ€™t over tighten them agist the other knuts or you can break parts. And when winding in lock two M4 knuts against each other. DO NOT USE PLIERS. The blocks then go on so that the belt can pass through them freely.
The Y axis belt clamps assembly has 6 M4 capture knuts in each side. These are standard knuts not lock nuts. This is all held together with the countersunk screws so as to keep the profile as low as possible.
The belts go round as normal but where they used to be clamped they go round the new baring brackets and back to the new clamps. Pull tight and clamp in line.
IMPORTANT. After installing you must exactly double the X and Y steps per mm in the firm where or it will only travel half the required distance.

comments.text: Wondering what's the best improvement for accuracy: a bowden cable or extra pulleys? Or both?

author: Books

title: Panel Mount for Inline Thermocouple Jack

description.text:
I needed to panel-mount a thermocouple jack on my crockpot controller but only found inline connectors for sale.  This holds the inline jack in a sleeve and provides a flange with mounting holes.
The design is parametric so should be adaptable for any connector with a rectangular cross-section, although I haven't tested with other dimensions so it might generate unexpected results.

Compare your connector dimensions to the those in the OpenSCAD file.  Buy a roll pin (best appearance but harder to remove later), cotter pin, or machine screw that fits the rivet hole (or just-'cause-you-need-a-hole hole) in your connector and a couple of machine screws and nuts to mount to the panel.
Print a panel mount, clean/drill out the holes as needed, and file out the sleeve as needed.
Press-fit the connector into the sleeve.  When you're sure you're ready, press-fit the roll pin through the sleeve and connector, then mount the flanged assembly on the panel and screw it in place.  Alternatively, screw the assembly to the panel, then install a cotter pin or machine screw through the sleeve and connector.

title: In Line Wire Connector With Strain Relief and Cover.

description.text: Connect 2 wires together with 6-32 flat screw like those used to mount computer hard drives. Threads are printed so use layer height .2 mm or less. max size about AWG 22. Do not over-tighten screw as clamping force can easily cut the wire. To use, strip ends about 3.8", twist together. Insert in hole in side of round part until it bottoms, install screw and install insulator/strain relief so wires come out ends as shown.  For extra protection you can add the optional second cover as shown in the second picture.

We were set on the path of designing this fidget during multimedia class. The project was to create a “fidget” item for a 5th grader with concentration problems. Our job was to create an object to help him focus on his work a school. The object needs to:
  • Be discrete
  • Have textures
    • This is by no means a finished project. If wanted, anyone can change it to suit your needs or finish the project themselves.
    Instructions: On a Replicator 2x ( or Makerbot Gen 5) you need to export your pencil toppa to makerbot. When it is on makerbot you need to add supports and after the pencil toppa is supported import Pencil Toppa to chip, then print. Spin topper once on pencil to secure.

comments.text: What program did you design this in?
comments.author: MeghanMatthews74014

description.text:
In our Design Studies class we were given a project of helping a child who has trouble focusing. We were given the challenge by our school division's occupational therapist who worked with us throughout the project. Linky is a fidget in the form of a chain with multiple textures that helps people who need something to assist them in concentrating on their task at hand. This fidget is customizable through colour, size, texture and shape. You can can mix and match different features in order to create something that is a very universal, yet specific all at the same time. We have added all skp. files for anyone who wants to modify the links. Please share these designs with other schools or groups that could use them, and comments or add photos of your printed Linky chains. Shaniece Drydgen
Jasmine Starman
Alisha Hancock
Grade 10 CLHS Design Studies
Print using no less than 20% fill. Default speed and heat, no supports or rafts. You connect the links together in order to create a chain with multiple links.

comments.text: A great set of chains for tactile feedback! I'm useing these as a fidget in class.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: There are a bunch of Pokemon on Thingiverse, but my favorite one was always missing...and now you don't need to swim up and down Cinnabar Island to find it. Uses Z-Stops to change "pixel" color. Tinkercad Link: https://tinkercad.com/things/kH2BPo52nA2 See instructions for more detail on how to print it.

The attached STL file is made to print with a raft (generated by MakerWare). The first (white) layer is 3.7mm tall, and you should set your first-Z pause to 5mm (raft is included in the z-pause height). Each additional layer is 1mm tall, and you should increment your z-stop by 1mm between each layer: 1) Load White, Set Z-stop to 5mm
2) Load Purple, Set Z-stop to 6mm
3) Load Grey/Light Purple, Set Z-stop to 7mm
4) Load Peach, Set Z-stop to 8mm
5) Load Black, wait for print to finish! The description has a link to the Tinkercad project, which has 5 separate STLs, one for each color. They are laid on top of each other, with an origin marker in the upper left corner (which you could delete in netfabb or similar). You can adjust the extrusion height in Tinkercad if you want a different configuration for your printer.

I own a Team Associated RC10gt, which is a 1/10 scale nitro truggy and/or truck. I took an old tired off of one of the wheels, used a caliper to measure the dimensions of the wheel, and deigned it on Solidworks. I will be making more variations of the standard wheel to come. hopefully the measurements to work well on my/your rc car (if you decide to print it on a 3D printer like I will be). Let me know how it works if you make one!

Apparently there has been some trouble with sizing (inches to millimeters) and should be around 2.4"x2.4"x1.96" while it is sitting on flat front part of the wheel. If it is too small, because of millimeters, then size it up by 25.4.

author: mouse9911

description.text: made by Alyssa

Using a Motorola Droid Window Mount and this bracket allows you to cleanly mount your 2013 Nexus 7 tablet in your car. The Google Nexus Wireless Charger fits into the included pocket and allows you to drop your tablet in and ensure that it is fully charged when you arrive at your destination. In addition the bracket allows easy access to all of the tablet's controls and ports. Do you have another device that you'd like to work with this mounting solution? Leave a comment, and I'll see what I can do! Note: This part is compatible with any windshield mount that uses the same interface as the Motorola arm mentioned above. I have listed several other arms below that I believe will work. If you have a mount that does work, please let me know in the comments and I will add it to the list below.
  • Motorola Droid Window Mount (Confirmed to work)

  • Insert a mandrel

  • Clamp it down

  • Wind some springs

description.text:
As one might have concluded, this thing isn't very practical! But it works. Read about how I made it here:
http://3dprint.com/43826/3d-printed-dishwasher/ Here is a video of the thing in use:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v_UEaiefYhA

Notice that you need to download the RAR-file and print all parts separately. I don't know how well it works to print the entire assembly at the same time. It might work on a Powder Bed Fusion printer, but it would be really hard in a regular FDM printer. The tap attachment might not fit on your tap, it is specificly made to fit on my tap and I don't know which standards there are in the tap industry. A tip would be to measure your tap before the print, so it's size isn't completly wrong.
The outside diameter of the threds on my tap is about 21.5 mm, and the pitch is about 1 mm. If your tap is in about the same size as mine and doesn't fit, you could try the other sizes of tap attachments that I've included in the RAR-file. When the print is done, you simply attach a dish brush on the thing with cable ties, and you are ready to go!

title: Modified Pack n Play caddy hook

description.text: I have a pack n play caddy (place to put odd and ends) made by Graco to fit on the end of their pack n play travel cribs. I do not have a grace pack n play but a Nuna Sena play yard. The Nuna has thicker rails and i needed to create hooks that would be compatible with Graco's caddy but fit over the Nuna's larger diameter rails. I created the model in openSCAD and it should ideally be easily modifiable.... but no promises.
I printed it in PLA on a Printrbot Simple Metal. I did a 10% hex fill and it ended up being much stiffer than I needed. I used a 0.4 mm layer height because it was such a simple shape.
